title: The following is a list of the most helpful sources for writing this book. I have included a few comments about just how helpful each of the volumes was
Inventing the Internet
A complete look at the early days of the Internet
A History of Modern Computing
Yes, there were computers before the Internet. This is for serious students only
The Internet Book
Good Internet background, but for real beginners. Showing its age, so use it as a history book
If you only read one book on routing basics, read this one for the IGPs
Routing TCP/IP
Covers BGP, multicast, IPv6, and much more
Juniper Networks Routers
A truly gigantic book covering all of the basics of Juniper Networks routers
TCP/IP
Excellent perspective on TCP/IP from the user point of view. Despite the title, this book contains a lot about routers and routing
How the Web was Born
The most complete history of the development of the Web at CERN by one of the principals (Cailliau

note: etc. Not long on explanation. But I found myself looking up command syntax again and again. The most used of all my Cisco books.
title: Internet Routing Architectures
Update of an old classic. This has always been just “the BGP book
Cisco Field Manual: Router Configuration
A very good reference for checking command syntax
Routing in the Internet
Very good book on IGP/EGP issues and answers. Vendor-neutral, which is almost a rare thing today
ISP Survival Guide
Many of the labs in this book were based on issues raised by this fine book on real-world ISP situations
Cisco Router Configuration
For beginners. Useful for edge or site router configuration, but not much else
Cisco TCP/IP Routing Professional Reference
Not very useful beyond RIP and the usual basics

note: Java, UNIX, Linux, and so on.
title: Go To
Nice look at what all those Internet routers are hooking up and carrying. A history of software ending with the Web
Big Book of Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) RFCs
What a book! Just having a complete index to all of these RFCs is worth the price. This is one of a whole series that includes other networking and routing concepts as well
OSPF
OSPF from the man who wrote the RFCs. Sometimes the going gets heavy, but it’s all there
I keep going back to this book when I need a quick look at the essentials of one TCP/IP feature or another
Building Scaleable Cisco Networks
Very good for practical examples of OSPF and BGP configurations

note: However, for the total amount of BGP information, there is none better.
title: Cisco BGP-4 Command and Configuration Handbook
Very helpful, but the numerous example configurations and show commands tend to clutter up the text and break up the flow
Interconnections
Read Perlman not only for IS-IS, but for LANs, bridging, and her wry take on the entire industry
The Soul of the Internet
I have many other books on Internet history, but this is the one I use the most
Very broad in range, it covers everything a router can do
IP Routing Fundamentals
Sound book on routing basics
The Protocols

Simply the classic book on TCP/IP. The late Stevens’ approach to TCP/IP, which was to do the same thing on different platforms and see what happened, inspired my own approach to do the same with routers in this book. Still the best for all but the latest tweaks and features
BGP4
Do not underestimate the importance of this slim volume. I found myself drawn to it again and again
Cisco: A Beginner’s Guide
This is for real beginners; it assumes no knowledge even of Cisco as a company
IP Routing Primer
An absolute beginners guide to Cisco routers. Covers static routing and default routing in detail, but not much else
